children.name: town
children.definition: a large area with houses, shops, offices etc where people live and work, that is smaller than a city and larger than a village : thị trấn , thị xã
examples: an industrial town in the Midlands
the town of Warrington/Poitiers/Kimball etc[written]
A large sign announced that we were entering the town of Knock.
the town of Norwalk, Connecticut
small/bigI grew up in a small town in Iowa.|The nearest big town is 20 miles away.
a little towna pretty little town in the French Alps
a major townIt is one of the UK’s biggest retailers with shops in every major town.
busy/bustlingThe town was busy even in November.
quietThe town is quiet in the summer.|Cannigione is a quiet little town with a scattering of shops, restaurants and cafes.
sleepy(= very quiet, with not much happening )Johnson grew up in the sleepy retirement town of Asheville.
a historic/ancient townVisitors can go on a tour of this historic town.
an industrial townThousands moved to the newly forming industrial towns to work in the mills.
a seaside townyoung people looking for seasonal work in seaside towns
a provincial town(= one that is not near the capital )Many provincial towns were transformed by the coming of the railway.
a market town(= a town in Britain where there is a regular outdoor market )The pretty market town of Ashbourne is only 9 miles away.
sb’s home town(= the town where someone was born )He was buried in his home town of Leeds.
a new town(= one of several towns built in Britain since 1946 )The design of Milton Keynes and other new towns proved unpopular.
the centre of town/the town centreBritish English,the center of town/the town centerAmerican English The hotel was right in the center of town.
the outskirts/edge of a townIt was six o'clock when she reached the outskirts of the town.
part of town
Steyne Street was a narrow street in a shabby but respectable part of town.
town[attri adj]
The town council has proposed a new road building project.
With better town planning, traffic problems could be avoided.
town squarea square in the centre of a town
A market is held daily in the town square.

children.name: city
children.definition: abigandimportanttown that is often the centre of government for an area, has a lot of trade and industry, and is likely to contain important political, educational, or religious institutions:thành phố
examples: The nearest big city was St. Louis.
the city of Belfast/Jerusalem/Boston etc[written]
The city of Barcelona is famous for its wonderful architecture.
the ancient city of Damascus
a big/large/major cityThey have stores in Houston, Dallas, and other big cities.
a great city(= very important and interesting )Cairo is one of the world's great cities.
a capital city(= where the government of a country or state is )Cuba's capital city is Havana.
sb’s home/native city(= where they were born or grew up )He said that he never wanted to leave his home city.
a cosmopolitan city(= full of people from different parts of the world )San Francisco is a very cosmopolitan city.
an industrial citySheffield is an industrial city in the north of England.
a provincial city(= in a part of the country that is not near the capital )There have been protests in the capital and in provincial cities.
an ancient citythe ancient city of Jerusalem
a historic city(= very old and with an interesting history )Budapest is a beautiful and historic city.
a cathedral city(= with a cathedral )He went to university in the cathedral city of Durham.
a university city(= with a university )Uppsala is a university city.
a walled city(= surrounded by a wall )the old walled city of Alghero
a twin cityUK(= one that has a special relationship with a similar town in another country )Strasbourg is Leicester's twin city in France.
a garden city[UK] a town that has been planned to include a lot of trees, plants and open spaces : thành phố xanh
the city centreBritish English,the city centerAmerican English The hotel is in the city centre.
the city limitsAmerican English(= the furthest parts of the city )rural areas south of the city limits
a city dweller(= someone who lives in a city )In the summer, city dwellers escape to the sea.
city lifethe advantages of city life
a city streetTraffic was moving slowly along the city streets.
in the heart of a cityThe cathedral is right in the heart of the city.
the outskirts of a city(= the edge )There were several bombings on the outskirts of the city.
found a city(= start developing a new city )He founded the city of Baghdad in the 8th century.
city[attri adj] relating to or in a city:
The city library cost over $15 million to build.
Residents blame city officials for poor housing conditions.
the city authorities
city streets
Beneath the city streets is a network of sewers.
city life
City life is becoming increasingly dangerous.

children.name: village
children.definition: a very small town in the country:làng
examples: There are some nice little pubs in the villages round here.
She left her village in the north of Thailand and went to live in Bangkok.
a little fishing village
small/little/tinyThey come from a small village in Laos.
pretty/picturesqueThere are many pretty villages nearby.
remote(= one that is far away from larger towns )We need to get food aid to the more remote villages.
quiet/sleepy(= one where there is not a lot of activity )Downham was a sleepy little village, with a road barely wide enough for one car.
a fishing villageOnce a fishing village, this is now a friendly, lively international resort.
a mountain/hilltop villageThe paths lead to picturesque mountain villages.
village[attri adj][UK]relating to a village:
There is a village festival every year at the beginning of May.
Has village life changed significantly in the last few years?
village shop/school/hall etc
We have a church, one pub and a village shop.
A meeting will be held at the village hall on Tuesday.
the village green(= area of grass for everyone to use )a cricket match on the village green
village life(= all the activities in a village )She had always taken an active part in village life.

children.name: settlement
children.definition: a place where people come to live for the first time and where they build a village or town, especially where few people have lived before : nơi an cư, nơi định cư
examples: She lived in a small settlement on the edge of the desert.
Settlements started to appear all along the river.
The tools were found in an early Iron Age settlement.
settlement[U] [C2] when a lot of people move to a place in order to live there, especially in a place where not many people have lived before : định cư, an cư
settlement of
the settlement of the American West
Many Native Americans were killed during the settlementofthe American West by Europeans in the nineteenth century.

children.name: port
children.definition: a town or city with a harbour or docks where ships can be loaded or unloaded : thành phố cảng
examples: Britain’s largest port
a naval/fishing/container port
We had a good view of all the shipscoming into/leavingport

children.name: the town where you are from
home town
children.definition: / hometown  the town where you were born, where you lived as a child, or where you live now: thành phố quê hương
examples: Sarajevo is my home town and I did not want to leave.
He was born in Bristol, but he considers London his home town since he's lived there most of his life.
home town of
Johnson lived in Seattle for ten years before returning to his home town of Cody, Wyoming.

children.name: home
children.definition: the place where you were born or the place where you usually live, especially if this is where you feel happy and want to live: quê nhà
examples: Her home, she said, was in Hong Kong, but she hadn’t been there since she was a child.
feel like home
I’ve lived in Madrid for many years, and it feels like home to me now.

children.name: relating to towns, cities in general
urban
children.definition: relating to towns and cities, the people who live in them, or the things that happen in them: thành thị
examples: The problem of air pollution is especially serious inurban areas.
China’s growing urban population
urban development/growth
post-war urban planning

children.name: civic
children.definition: relating to the government of a city or town: đô thị, thành phố, thị xã
examples: An important civic function is taking place in the city hall this evening.
Harlow Council has always been generous with civic funding for music and the arts.
The Prime Minister met many civicleaders, including the mayor and the leaders of the immigrant communities.
She felt it was her civicduty(= her duty as a person living in the town) to tell the police.
The opera house is a great source of civicpride.

children.name: municipal
children.definition: relating to the government of a town or city or to the public services it provides: thành phố, thị xã, đô thị
examples: Municipal elections will be held on April 12th.
Not far from the town centre is the municipal park.
The museum and other municipal buildings are threatened.

children.name: capital
children.definition: the town or city where the government of a country or area is: thủ đô, thủ phủ
examples: Rome is one of the world’s most beautiful capitals.
capital of
What’s the capital of Canada?
capital city
The tour includes a trip to Budapest, Hungary’s capital city.
state/regional/provincial etc capital
Sacramento is the state capital of California.

children.name: metropolis
children.definition: the largest, most important city in a country or area - use this especially to emphasize that a city is busy and full of people and activity: thủ đô
examples: After 1850 Paris grew quickly into a busy metropolis.
They drove quickly, leaving the immense metropolis behind them.
metropolis of
Our aim is to make Sydney the musical metropolis of the world.
metropolitan[attri adj] relating to a large city:
Some workers can only afford homes outside metropolitan areas.
the metropolitan authorities
the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York
He was drawn to the metropolitan glamour and excitement of Paris.
a metropolitan area/council
